Media

Class Pixel

  • java.lang.Object
    • Media.Pixel

  • public class Pixel
extends java.lang.Object
    A pixel is a single point (picture element) in a Picture. A Pixel stores its red, green, blue, and transparency values. When on a BasicForm Canvas, the pixel will inform the Canvas of a change so that pixel changes occur in real time. In the current implementation only the last canvas the picture is placed on will be informed.
    Version:
    1.0 Date (06/06/02), 2.0 2007, 3.0 June 2008, 4.0 (08/08/26), 5.0 (09/05/04), 6.0 (10/06/14)
    Author:
    Michael Pickard, Mark Elgersma, Andrew Cheesman, David Hughes, David Hughes, David Hughes

        int the color distance

      • getRed

        public int getRed()
        This method returns the red value of the pixel. As the pixel is stored as a Byte, it needs to be modified slightly for a 0-255 range instead of -128 to 127
        Returns:
        int (the red value in the range 0-255)

      • getGreen

        public int getGreen()
        This method returns the green value of the pixel. As the pixel is stored as a Byte, it needs to be modified slightly for a 0-255 range instead of -128 to 127
        Returns:
        int (the green value in the range 0-255)

      • getBlue

        public int getBlue()
        This method returns the blue value of the pixel. As the pixel is stored as a Byte, it needs to be modified slightly for a 0-255 range instead of -128 to 127
        Returns:
        int (the blue value in the range 0-255)

      • getTransparency

        public byte getTransparency()
        This method returns the transparency value of the pixel.
        Returns:
        byte (the transparency value of the pixel)

      • setRed

        public void setRed(int r)
        This method sets the red value of the pixel. It treats the 0-255 range as a continuum (thus a value of 256 would be set to 0).
        Parameters:
        r - (the new red value)

      • setGreen

        public void setGreen(int g)
        This method sets the green value of the pixel. It treats the 0-255 range as a continuum (thus a value of 256 would be set to 0).
        Parameters:
        g - (the new green value)
